description: Numbers n such that d(n)^2 divides phi(n) + sigma(n).
comments: Makowski proved that phi(n)+Sigma[n] = n*d[n] iff n is a prime (see in Sivaramakrishnan, Chapter I, page 8, Theorem 3).
references: Sivaramakrishnan, R. (1989), Classical Theory of Arithmetical Functions, Marcel Dekker, Inc., New York-Basel.
formula: Integer solutions of Phi[x]+Sigma[x] = kd[x]^2 or A000203(n)+A000010(n) = k*A000005(n)^2, where k is integer.
example: true for 2 (the only prime) and some composites. n = 78: 8 divisors, Sigma = 168, Phi = 24, 168+24 = 192 = 8*8*3
author: _Labos Elemer_, Jun 27 2000
